reviews.text: Thanks to All of you for a wonderful honeymoon dinner . Bussi from vienna <3

Absolutely incredible! Every dish was a delight, and the wine and IPA pairings elevated the experience even more. The staff were warm, attentive, and refreshingly down-to-earthâ€”none of the pretentiousness you sometimes find at high-end spots. Blancaâ€™s has quickly become one of my new favorite places. A must-try!
Very disappointed. We made a reservation and arrived at the door only to find out itâ€™s closed permanently. Didnâ€™t get any notification or calls. Donâ€™t come!!

An incredible experience! It managed to be a very surprising, yet cohesive meal. Perfect place for our anniversary! Most of the protein was seafood based, and frankly the beef dishes were our least favorite of the evening. Perhaps because I was getting full and they were at the end. Really glorious meal! Only Blanca pre-pandemic and a couple of meals in Japan for our honeymoon rival it!

If you are tired of the same menu, same ingredients, and similar plating, this is a good place to expect a little surprise. You will be surprised by the daily changing menu of the female chef from Chile, South America. I was also surprised by the fact that it is located in a pizza place that I have visited several times before. You have to get directions through the pizza place to enter. They say that the price also changes every time because the ingredients and menu change every time.

It is a place I want to visit again.
Outstanding. Everything was perfect.

The chef Is very snooty and entitled doesn't wan't pictures but works in an open kitchen. The Food was bland
She literally managed to mess up Gotham's legacy and is now definitely messing up Blanca's legacy with the same washed up cuisine that any real chef can see right through.
awesome. foodies will love.

I use to be a big fan of the â€œoldâ€ Blanca  and I was eager  for coming back . Sadly it was a huge disappointment. Friday night and we were just 6 people dinning at the counter , the attitude  and mood of the staff was always friendly but with a sensation of being so bored (nothing like the old team) . The food was not so bad to say the best , I canâ€™t even remember what they served ,totally unforgettable â€¦. New chef Blamey wasnâ€™t there . Hope  owners Carlo and Brandon can safe what  was one of the top restaurants in NY
Super!!!!

In short, food was not commensurate to the price point. No particularly delicious nor memorable dishes and at the same cost Iâ€™ve had stellar meals at places like Odo and Oiji Mi.

The house staff were nice. The wine pairing was the best part of the meal. What really soured me was when a particular dish which was to be served then topped with consommÃ© came to us, we didnâ€™t catch that we were supposed to wait for the consommÃ©. It arrived several minutes after the dish was served. So we ate, and finished it, before then. We were not bothered, it was a fine dish anyway. Whether or not we were told this and missed it, or were not told it, is really beside the point, as we had no complaints.

The issue was, when chef came to top with consommÃ© she was understandably bothered. But instead of being gracious or taking it in stride, her dour attitude was immediately palpable and she left curtly. One of the hosts soon returned to serve us the soup separately. At this point all I or my wife had said was, literally, â€œsorryâ€ (though, what did we have to be sorry for?). Unfortunately instead of saying anything remotely accountable, he basically said â€œchef was so mad at me, but Iâ€™m sure I told you to wait!â€ At that point I started to feel more like an employee than a guest. Sorry but, did I eat the food I payed for wrong? Is that my fault? Then, to make an awkward situation unforgivable, while serving the next dish to the party before us, chef mentioned to take care as it was hot enough to scald. Then she notes, while chatting with them, how so many reviews have mentioned that this particular dish is served too hot, and despite her warning, people still complain. Fine I guess, but, shouldnâ€™t you know how to serve food at the right temperature? Maybe as the one in control you should do your part such that the problem canâ€™t exist, and you arenâ€™t creating the potential for an undesirable outcome? It sounded familiar. Then as she serves us, while still speaking to them, she says â€œsome people just donâ€™t listenâ€. That sent me.

I do not work for you. For something to go wrong and you offer pleas of innocence directly to me, let alone make me feel somehow guilty for it, is the most antithetical and absurd thing I have ever encountered during a meal. I felt like I was in a TV show. Put your ego away. I donâ€™t care. I can say with certainty that whatever fuss was made over this non-incident, had the soup been added [at the time of service, as it should have beenâ€¦], it would have had no effect on the dish. Not only did it not matter, and was not an issue until the chef made it one and terrified the staff into shirking responsibility, it was absurd to blame me.

Ultimately the amount I paid compared to the meal I ate and the experience I had was upsetting. Even outside of this, I was underwhelmed by the menu and would not recommend it if youâ€™re looking for a great meal. The seafood dishes failed to highlight the best qualities of each protein, generally being overwhelmingly oceanic â€” some unpleasantly so, such as the oysters and skipjack. The chard, despite its sauce, was just chard, chewy and vegetal. The bread, empanadas, and aged pork were the only tasty items, of which only the bread was standout.

Basically the food was ok, experience surreal, and overall, this place at best made me appreciate the other fine dining experiences Iâ€™ve had even more.

I had dinner there and lost my wallet (either at restaurant or my way home). There is NO way to contact them by phone. I tried calling multiple times and no one is ever available. Also i sent 2 emails and they DO NOT RESPOND!!. Super annoying.
The food is amazing, and the service is great. Highly recommend.

I had the pleasure of dining  here a few weeks ago.
Blanca provides a dining experience that is both groundbreaking and extraordinary, with each dish showcasing an exceptional blend of creativity and precision. The culinary team pushes the limits of innovation, employing cutting-edge techniques and unexpected ingredient combinations to transform every plate into a culinary experience.
Listed below are some of the dishes that I thought was worth mentioning:

Swiss Chard with White Chocolate Sauce
This dish was exceptionally well-prepared. The creamy texture of the Swiss chard was complemented by the delicate white chocolate sauce, which enhanced the overall flavor profile without overwhelming the vegetableâ€™s natural taste. The balance between the savory and sweet elements was executed perfectly, offering a unique and refined experience.

Monkfish Liver
While this dish may not appeal to everyone, it was an interesting exploration of flavors. The robust savory notes of the monkfish liver were well-matched with the candied pomegranate, creating a harmonious contrast. The texture was spread-like, and the slight fishiness was not overpowering. Personally, I found the monkfish liver challenging, but I do appreciate the thoughtful combination of flavor profiles it presents

Belon oyster
This dish was innovative and one of the highlights of the evening. Everything was perfectly balanced, and the combination of the oyster with fermented elements and dried mackerel was both creative and delightful, making it a standout favorite.

The plantain was prepared, with a satisfying kick that added a pleasant depth to the dish. The tuna was also quite impressive, with the onion sauce providing a perfect complement to the fishâ€™s richness.

The halibut, unfortunately, was not to my taste. The presence of bones and the unusual texture made it feel unbalanced, both in flavor and overall execution.

The Dungeness crab dish, however, was truly exceptional. The empanada-shaped presentation, resembling a crab, was a brilliant touch. The pairing of CuraÃ§ao was particularly noteworthy, enhancing the flavors

The bread dish was a revelationâ€”impressive enough to stand alone. While some might find it slightly salty, I found it to be a remarkable addition to the meal.

The rice and pork dish stood out, with the rice being particularly flavorful. However, I would suggest using flat plates instead of bowls, as my bowl kept shifting while I was cutting the dish. The sauce emulsion was excellent, pairing beautifully with the entire dish.

Lastly, I appreciated the unique concept of the palate cleanser being a drink. Something different for an experience. And also that the first and last course starts with tea. Great touch!

Overall, it was an incredibly enjoyable experience. Chef Victoria and her team truly excel, showcasing remarkable talent and creativity in every dish. Allenâ€™s service was exceptional, with a level of professionalism and attentiveness worth noting. Luis demonstrated great knowledge in presenting the food, enhancing the overall dining experience. Additionally, Benjaminâ€™s beverage pairing recommendations were spot-on, further complementing the flavors of each course.
Expensive tasting meal worth every penny.  Wine pairing add-on is pretty amazing. You'll have a good 6 full pours throughout the meal.

Most toppest-tier extended tasting menu spots in NY leave me a bit cold - the ultra-refinement feels sterile and saps the joy and discovery of a Noma, Gaggan, or Quintonil.  EMP at its (pre-Vegan) height bored me, Atomix is obviously excellent but I vastly prefer the food and soul of Atoboy (maybe itâ€™s just the chicken, but still - also Iâ€™ve never been to Le Bernardin so no shade to them).

Blanca, however, is now the one in the city Iâ€™d slot with my favorites ever - the first in the city since the initial iteration of Ko.

Certainly it has refinement to spare, but almost every dish presents diners with combinations which seem dubious at first - but after the first few conquer your palate youâ€™ll be along for the ride, salivating over what discordant thrills Blamey masters as if born concocting them.

And that bread courseâ€¦Iâ€™ll never forget it.

Thank you Blanca!!
thank you all , chef victoria you have an amazing team. the dinner was amazing, see you soon.

My brother and I visited Blanca to celebrate his graduation, and we couldnâ€™t have made a better choice! We discovered this place through the NYT list, where Blanca is rated #2 in all of New York, and I cannot disagree! Everything was incredibly creative while being very cohesive; itâ€™s hard to pick a favorite! The pairing was also incredible, and the service and ambiance were amazing. The music was the best partâ€”well, other than the food, of course. Thank you, Chef Victoria Blamey, and the entire crew behind her for an experience my brother and I will never forget!

This place is for those who appreciate self expression in a form of food and sense of taste. The experience is fun if you are curious about food and enjoy trying to guess things out. Whatâ€™s the ingredient that leaves that crazy flavor? How did the chef got to that dish? Every dish has a story.

Watch the food being prepared by the chef while the team performs a highly coordinated experience serving the guests.

Also LOVE that the spot is located in a hidden door inside of another place in Bushwick and far away from the Manhattan BS. The contrast of having a fine dining in my trashy neighborhood makes the experience even cooler. ðŸ˜Ž IYKYK

My partner and I came with our hearts open and we left fulfilled with our soul fed.

I visited Blanca with my husband for a special birthday dinner, but unfortunately, the experience fell short of expectations.

Finding the entrance was tricky, and we ended up at the tiki bar outside. From there, we were directed to a dimly lit, extremely grungy bar with red lighting where we had to wait for someone to escort us to the restaurant itself. The vibe felt like it was trying hard to appear effortless, with minimal decorâ€”a fish head on the wall and an open kitchen with a counter in front of it.

The food was highly experimental (think sorbet with tomatoes), and while creativity is appreciated, it left me feeling underwhelmed. Apart from the tuna strips, nothing truly impressed me. For the steep price point, we were left waiting for that 'wow' moment that never came, and left pretty disappointed.

Had I known how underwhelming the meal would be, I probably would have chosen a different place for such a special occasion.

Even tho itâ€™s a pretty big price the staff is super down to earth and makes you feel welcome. I donâ€™t usually eat at these sorts of places but Blanca has a good way with folks and not intimidating you. The food was really good & imaginative, highlight was this uni dish cuz I never actually got to try that before. You definitely leave feeling satisfied and not overly full or super hungry. The head chef even comes out and talks to you about a couple courses, makes jokes, all very friendly vibes

EVERYTHING was absolutely incredible!
Five stars just doesnâ€™t seem like enough-

I walked into Robertaâ€™s a little confused. Where is Blanca? Did I miss the entrance? A quick inquiry with the hostess, and I was told to wait by the bar for the maitre dâ€™. After being welcomed in, I was guided through a swarm of Friday night beer drinkers and momâ€™s with strollers enjoying their pizza to the semi-hidden entrance of Blanca. It was a good vibe at Robertaâ€™s, and I entered Blanca with an upbeat air, excited for the nightâ€™s journey. Unfortunately, by the time I left, my mood was dampened. Itâ€™s hard to pinpoint, but there was something uncomfortable about the dining experience. Blue Hill, without the Farm Tour. Alinea, without the innovation. Atomix, without the art. The Menu, without the murders.

Blanca is sparse â€” a high top bar, seated side by side with other Brooklynites celebrating birthdays and anniversaries, surrounding an open kitchen that puts everyone on equal footing to observe the â€œdanceâ€ of the kitchen. The space feels informal, and itâ€™s meant to be fun. Unfortunately, the same canâ€™t be said of the chef. When I snapped some photos of the smoldering flames on the charcoal grill, she came up and scolded me, telling me Iâ€™m only allowed to take pictures of my own food. When I tried looking up an ingredient on my phone as she was explaining one of the dishes, she stopped me to ask if I was paying attention. Observing the other diners at the bar, it seemed like they were all basking in the attention of the star chef. She reminds me of Anton Ego from ratatouille BEFORE he tasted the ratatouille.

The food itself was a mixed bag. Some standouts included the Winter Point Oyster with fermented calamansi, the Crab Empanada, and the Tortilla Al Rescoldo, a fantastic take on a classic Chilean bread stuffed with lamb belly. Unfortunately, these delicious bites were offset by numerous courses that felt half baked â€” Tomato with rambutan, Easter Egg Radish with grated cheese, and the Summer Fruit sorbet with tomato all felt like they were trying too hard to take advantage of â€˜Tomato Seasonâ€™, while completely disregarding the chefâ€™s strengths.

On top of that, the ambiguous explanation of foreign ingredients left me feeling confused. There was something that resembled plant stems but tasted like corn.  Some edible cactus-looking flower with leaves that had spikes on them that ended up cutting the inside of my mouth. Itâ€™s as if the chef is pressured into using exotic ingredients and shock factor to justify the price. You either accept that you donâ€™t know what youâ€™re eating or youâ€™re figuring out how to spell â€˜fri-ka?â€™ â€˜free-cah?â€™ in Google.

Eating here felt like a puzzle.  Most flavours felt overly complicated, yet subpar in terms of memorability. This thumb size spinach roll on a bed of miso dressing and jellied something, basically Goma-ae, a common japanese chilled spinach side dish, presented as if itâ€™s innovative.

At Blanca, weâ€™re supposed to appreciate the natural tastes of global and local flora and fauna. That said, I just came from Peru and preferred the myriad varietals of street corn and potatoes to anything that Blanca has to offer.

At $275 and an additional $175 for wine pairing, was it a meal that left me satiated? It was not. There was air of pretentiousness but overall, the experience was just â€˜midâ€™. The bread with lamb belly was fantastic. The oyster and empanada both very good, but put enough fat and butter on anything...

The lamb entree was quite tough, but with good flavors. All the seasonal vegetable preparations were severely lacking.

Would I go back? No, Iâ€™d rather have taken a seat at Robertaâ€™s.
Amazing experience. Went last night and had the best time. Deserves Michelin stars. Thank you for pouring me drinks for free and giving me suck a Kappo experience!!
10/10 all around
Essen, Service, Musik, Theke und Wein - alles fein.
Mostly excellent!
We enjoyed the food, the wine and the whole experience! Thanks!
Small plates, hyper vigilant and interactive staff, every dish has a backstory. Bring a jacket the AC has two settings high and off. This is a food experience, lots of fermented things.

Had a truly amazing birthday here. Service was next level (especially thank you to Kim and Mia but everyone was), non-alcoholic beverages were awesome too (sparkling teas??). Had the best oyster I've ever had, a perfect tempura leaf, beautiful smoked and raw fish, and tender lamb with perfectly rendered fat. Many many thanks

Vibe: awesome, loved the layout, the music, the smokiness of the whole space. Service: great, all the staff were sweet and enthusiastic. Food: unfortunately mid. Very, very mid. Out of the 16 courses I liked 5 of them. The uni dish, Spanish mackerel, snail pasta dish, bread with chicharon (this was shockingly amazing, shocking because it legit looked like a lump of coal), and the palate cleanser with apple cider granita was bomb. But everything else was not memorable. Also my friend and I both had terrible stomachaches after getting home, so that wasnâ€™t so great either. Probably wonâ€™t be going back but glad we tried it.
Clearly unique. Probably best restaurant in NY. Chef Victoria reaches superb equilibrium of flavor and originality. Service was amazing

6 years since my last visit, and things have changed a lot yet also remained the same. Prices have creeped up since but we still found great value for the wine, a 2014 Gevrey-Chambertin that didnt break the bank and drank really well. Some standouts: torched uni, crab empanada, caviar over white chocolate ice cream and bread with literal pieces of pork in it. Great stuff Blanca team!

Blanca finally reopened and I was so excited to finally go back. The last time I visited was late 2019, and it was a magical experience and probably my favorite tasting in all of New York. It was an approachable one that didnâ€™t try to be too experimental and each dish was incredible.

I went back to Blanca in April 2024 and was so disappointed. The concept has changed from Italian to a sloppy fusion of cuisines including Chilean, Pacific island, and Spanish. The pastas were beyond average, lacking the mind blowing flavor they used to have. One tasted like nothing and the second has lavender and bee pollen, so nothing to write home about. The meal lacked any cohesive story and flavor. And as a lover of uni, I canâ€™t believe they managed to make an uni dish that tasted like nothing!

A truly disappointing experience
Incredible food especially the roasted pheasant and omelette with onion broth, garlic mustard greens, and sansho pepper

This is the epitome of a fine dining experience and establishment. Chef Victoria and her team delivers exceptionally curated dishes with each and every bite. Each one packed with bold flavors, textures, and aroma. The open space itself was the perfect setting. From the beautiful ceramics to the perfectly curated music. **Highly recommended**

My wife and I were so happy when we learned Blanca was reopening after closing due to COVID-19.  Our only worry was. Will it be as good as it was before it closed?  Well, let me tell you, it's even better than before.  The menu was perfect each plate better than the last.  The best part of the night was the staff.  The entire staff at Blanca is so friendly and goes above and beyond to make the night great.  Can't wait to go back!!
Will this place ever reopen?
Hands down best in north America and world class dining experience. I miss them a lot!
Very late review: Blanca is the best restaurant you can find in NYC. Visited twice and both times were amazing ðŸ¥°â€¦

blanca is THE finest restaurant in New York City. 17 course tasting menu of astonishing creativity, unlike anything you will ever experience. There are no tables at Blanca, instead there is a a long white bar with captain's chairs in full view of the open kitchen. The staff are kind, knowledgeable, and passionate about the food, and the wine list runs to rare gems you've never heard of and probably won't ever be able to find in retail markets. Eating here is a special treat, well worth the difficulty of getting a reservation.

Bonus: if you're still hungry, Roberta's take-out pizza is right next door.

Hands down my favorite restaurant in the world.

The quality of food and service grossly out weighs any other restaurant of this caliber. Much more relaxed in dress and feel, all while maintaining white cloth grade attentions. A constant variety of music pulls you on a journey while the always changing menu of divine food enlightens the soul. Main stay dishes come in many variables throughout the year, making a monthly visit all the more worth it.

Laughter and happiness is sure to ensue in this Brooklyn staple.

Fantastic experience. Friendly, warm, welcoming staff.  Great service that didnâ€™t feel too stuffy for a fine dining restaurant.  Great variety of food with unique, well thought out flavor combinations.... 20 courses.  Fun music selections with the record player spinning in the background.

I purchased a gift certificate as a holiday present,  in a substantial amount from here. It was a pain to get. Let's just say that  service left alot to be desired. For a two michelin star restaurant, i would expect a lot more from their managing staff.  I would not recommend .
Wonderful time

Only 12 seats in this place to eat. You have to wait forever to get a reservation.  Then it's super expensive to eat there. Save your time and money and eat at little Italy in the Bronx.  A large variety of restaurants in a family owned enclave. And reasonable prices.

One of the best food experiences ever in my life. Thank you!
Amazing food and service, truly a two Michelin star experience.
ì˜ˆìˆ ì´ë¼ê³  ë°–ì—. ìš”ì¦˜ ì½”ìŠ¤ìš”ë¦¬ ë©”ì¸ ë‚˜ì˜¤ê¸°ì „ì— ì§€ì³ìžˆë˜ ë‚˜ì—ê²Œ ìƒˆë¡œìš´ íž˜ì„ ì¤€ ê³³! ã…‹ ë‰´ìš•ì— ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  ë¸Œë£¨í´ë¦°ê¹Œì§€ ì°¾ì•„ê°ˆë§Œ í•œ ë©‹ì§„ ë ˆìŠ¤í† ëž‘, ë¸”ëž‘ì¹´!!

I got to tell ya...this was quite the experience. Went with a group of 4. They come and grab you at the bar collectively 5min before which is fun. Great and attentive service and everyone was super knowledgeable of the wine and food.

We did not do the wine pairing and just did two nice Italian bottles and that was perfect for the majority of the dishes we had.

I have done other tasting menus (DOM, Pujols, Quintonel), but this was by far the most expensive. With that said, the music was awesome setting a super chill mood, and I think you can requests songs (not 100% on song requests, but itâ€™s basically a playlist they preset and can alter).

Chefs were chill and their break down is fun to watch as it enters the end of the meal. 11/10 would recommend for an interesting Brooklyn Michelin star experience, amazing food, good vibes, good music.
Perfection.  Exactly what you'd expect.  Though every course wasn't 10/10, innovative flavors were interwoven throughout.  Wine pairing was adventurous and free flowing.  Casual vibe fitting.
Favorite tasting menu ever. Unfussy, decadent perfection in a perfect environment with great staff and even better music. Best in Brooklyn.

This is what a tasting menu is supposed to be. In every sense there is no better way to spend two hours eating, at any cost. Vinyl music playing, staff super friendly and helpful, and the food ... well. Just go. I've been all over the worldâ€¦

Genuine article. Well worth the arm and leg. Be sure to opt for the wine pairing. Staff is genuine, warm and attentive. Service flows naturally in a gorgeous space while a turntable spins real vinyls for music all night long. Everything far exceeded my already high expectations, truly transcendental dining experience and one of the best wine pairings Iâ€™ve ever had. Brava Blanca!

There is also an electronic bidet.
Amazing experience and worth the price.  About 12 courses. The flavors were unique and well balanced.
The 16-course menu was interesting, creative, and of course, delicious. Very intimate space and you see all the chefs prepare the dishes. I recommend getting sake with some of the dishes.
Excellent and light food. Comfortable atmosphere. Good people.

Another amazing meal at Blanca! Each course was a journey in varied flavors and textures and I loved our meal! There were a couple courses that weren't my favorite, though they were still interesting and worth a bite, but that is to be expected over 17 dishes. (Each course is maybe 2-3 bites.) The progression was logical and had a flow from appetizer-type dishes to main course type dishes to desserts. They were harmonious and well thought out. They were also beautiful to the eye.

The server and staff were all terrific. I like their lack of pretension (despite having 2 Michelin stars) and they were really interested in our having a great meal. They were friendly and able to answer any questions about a dish. The wine pairings (plus sake, cider and beer) were very well chosen to complement the courses. The attire is casual and guests who were there that night wore everything from jeans and hipster-hat to jacket and tie, but no judgments and everyone was made comfortable and welcome.

If I had one complaint, and this applies to pretty much all tasting menus, somewhere around course 13 I am completely beyond full and the last few courses (which here included the Wagyu beef) are very uncomfortable. I manage this by having a nibble of these courses and sending the rest over to my husband who has a much bigger capacity than I. But I would like a tasting menu allowing SOME guests to skip a few courses. It's not just Blanca, but pretty much every place I have done tasting menus (and that's a lot of places.) Still, other than the pain to the pocketbook, I would happily eat here regularly.

I can't recommend this restaurant highly enough. Its expensive, but in line with what you would expect from a chefs table experience. Our dinner was 16 courses with alcohol pairings (not just wine, but sake and beer too). Each and everyâ€¦

Outstanding tasting menu. Every dish amazed. The atmosphere was casual and relaxing. The staff were friendly, helpful, and fun. A totally different experience than sitting in a large dining room. The wine pairings were very well selected.
Secrete restaurant behind a pizza place (great as well), inventive menu, great presentation, nice seating with the view at the kitchen

Impeccable from start to finish. Ingredients are top notch, cooked creatively and perfectly and the menu flows beautifully. Atmosphere couldnâ€™t be better a fine dining party. One of my favorite restaurants in New York.

Blanca is not your typical chef's table experience. It's welcoming, personal, informal, laid-back and actually enjoyable. You could totally wear shorts here and not get glared at, which is my kind of place. I highly recommend thisâ€¦

This is one of my favorite tastings in NYC. Inside this huge pristine kitchen, each course is carefully curated from having different textures in each bite to having each ingredient compliment every other ingredient in each bite. Not many chefs take food to this level of creativity. Good luck getting a reservation.

I really enjoyed my 2.5-hour tasting course at Blanca. Having read other reviews on Yelp, I thought I might need to order a pizza at the end. Since you walk through Roberta's to get to Blanca, my bf and I eyed people's delicious-looking pizza on our way in. We checked in at where we were on the "pizza meter" throughout the night. At first we were at 100% pizza given that we were super hungry, but after the fresh dough course, he was down to 30% and we were full by the end of the dinner. They gave us ridiculously delicious smores as a treat to take home, too.

Each course is only a few bites, but they're packed with flavors and beautifully presented. To me, a great tasting menu like this requires two things: 1) inventive use of ingredients that 2) work well together aka taste is on point. Blanca achieved both of these with flying (minimalist) colors. Particular standouts to me were the garbanzo bean soup, apple with macadamia shavings that melted in the mouth, chewy and rich carbonara, nduja sausage ravioli, sunchoke cake with cardamom and chocolate for dessert, and the fresh dough. If you're asking yourself, how good can pizza dough taste? Try some when it's steaming hot. It really tastes that good.

I also much prefer this laid-back more casual environment without the pretension of some three-star Michelin restaurants like Per Se and Eleven Madison Park. It's not a place to be seen, but rather a place to focus on the food and the experience of watching people absorbed in their craft.
Open to only 12 diners per night, this spot is extremely difficult to get into. Once you snag a reservation, you'll be rewarded with an incredible 20+ course tasting menu. The pastas are all divine.
